comments.content:
using packet tracer i created a native vl mistmatch and did a sho cdp nei and got this ..Switch(config)#do sh cdp nei
Capability Codes: R - Router, T - Trans Bridge, B - Source Route Bridge
 S - Switch, H - Host, I - IGMP, r - Repeater, P - Phone
Device ID Local Intrfce Holdtme Capability Platform Port ID
Switch Gig 0/1 75 3560 Gig 0/1
Switch Gig 0/1 135 3560 Gig 0/1
Switch(config)#
%CDP-4-NATIVE_VLAN_MISMATCH: Native VLAN mismatch discovered on GigabitEthernet0/1 (1), with Switch GigabitEthernet0/1 (4).


considering the same switch shows up twice cdp is clearly affected...maybe not "disabled" but something's wrong so the answer is A&D

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Match the steps needed to configure RSPAN in the proper order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
Disagree with the order in this question, should be: -

Step 1. Configure a VLAN as an RSPAN VLAN
Step 2. Associate an RSPAN source session number with source ports or VLANs
Step 3. Associate an RSPAN destination session number with the RSPAN VLAN
Step 4. Associate an RSPAN source session number with the RSPAN VLAN
Step 5. Associate an RSPAN destination session number with a destination port

-On both local and remote switches >> Create RSPAN VLAN
-Create session with source port/VLAN
-Create Session with destiantion RSPAN VLan
On remote Switch
-Creat session source RSPAN VLAN
-Create session destination port

I suppose answer should be:
On the source switch
1. create destination VLAN for RSPAN
2. monitor session 1 source (int or VLAN) direct rx | tx | both
3. monitor session 1 destination remote vlan

On the destination switch:
1. create VLAN for RSPAN (source)
2. monitor session 1 source remote vlan
3. monitor session 1 destination int | VLAN

comments.content:
Explain: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst2960/software/release/12-2_40_se/configuration/guide/scg/swspan.pdf?dtid=osscdc000283

There's a some misunderstanding. )) 
I mean the same.

I agree with 2 and 3 for each, but why should 1. be that way around and not as below?
On the source switch
1. create destination VLAN for RSPAN (source)
2. monitor session 1 source (int or VLAN) direct rx | tx | both
3. monitor session 1 destination remote vlan

On the destination switch:
1. create VLAN for RSPAN (destination)
2. monitor session 1 source remote vlan
3. monitor session 1 destination int | VLAN

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Select and Place:
Select and Place:
//IMG//
Which information does the subordinate switch in a switch stack keep for all the VLANs that are configured on it?

discussion.content:
"Subordinate switches keep their own spanning trees for each VLAN that they support. The master switch keeps a copy of all spanning tree tables for each VLAN in the stack. When a new VLAN is added, or removed, all the existing switches will receive a notification of this event and update their tables accordingly."

https://community.cisco.com/kxiwq67737/attachments/kxiwq67737/6016-discussions-lan-switching-routing/132275/1/83489-stackwise_wp_0321.pdf
